## Diode Basics

- [Electronics Tutorials: Diodes](https://www.electronics-tutorials.ws/diode)

- A diode is a semiconductor device that allows current to flow in one direction only.

![Diode Overview](images/diode_overview.webp)

- **Forward Region**: Positive voltage on the anode allows current flow; exponentially increases with voltage.

- **Reverse Region**: Positive voltage on the cathode blocks current flow; very small leakage current.

- **Breakdown Region**: Sudden increase in current at high reverse voltage (Zener breakdown).

## Types of Diodes

- **Zener Diode**: Used for voltage regulation; operates in reverse breakdown region.

- **Schottky Diode**: Known for low forward voltage drop and fast switching speeds.

- **LED (Light Emitting Diode)**: Emits light when forward biased; used in displays and indicators.

- **Photodiode**: Generates current when exposed to light; used in solar cells and light sensors.

## Rectifiers

### Half-Wave Rectifier

**Half-Wave Rectifier**: Allows only one half of the AC waveform to pass; simple but inefficient.
  
![Half-Wave Rectifier](images/rectifier.webp){fig-align="center"}

![Transformer and Rectifier Circuit](images/transformer_rectifier.webp){fig-align="center"}

## How Much Power in Half-Wave Rectified Signal?

![Half-Wave Rectified Power](images/half_rectified_power.webp){fig-align="center"}

$$
V_{DC} = \frac{V_{peak}}{\pi} \quad , \quad P_{DC} = \frac{V_{DC}^2}{R} = \frac{V_{peak}^2}{\pi^2 R}
$$

![Half-Wave Rectifier with Smoothing Capacitor](images/half_wave_rect_w_cap.webp){fig-align="center"}

### Full-Wave Rectifier

- **Full-Wave Rectifier**: Utilizes both halves of the AC waveform; more efficient and provides smoother output.

![Full-Wave Rectifier](images/full_wave_rectifier.webp){fig-align="center"}

![Full-Wave Rectifier with Transformer](images/full_wave_rectifier_transformer.webp){fig-align="center"}

## Applications of Diodes
- Voltage regulation (Zener diodes)
- Signal demodulation
- Power conversion (rectifiers)
- Light emission (LEDs)
- Photodetection (photodiodes)
